articles.headline: Bundy Brothers Acquitted in Takeover of Oregon Wildlife Refuge
articles.snippet: Ammon and Ryan Bundy and five of their followers faced federal felony charges stemming from the six-week takeover in January.
articles.abstract: Ammon and Ryan Bundy and five of their followers faced federal felony charges stemming from the six-week takeover in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Armed antigovernment protesters led by Ammon and Ryan Bundy were acquitted Thursday of federal conspiracy and weapons charges stemming from the takeover of a federally owned wildlife sanctuary in Oregon last winter.
articles.byline: By Courtney Sherwood and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: More Wretched News for Newspapers as Advertising Woes Drive Anxiety
articles.snippet: News publications continue to be pummeled by rapidly declining print advertising revenue, and newsrooms everywhere are scrambling.
articles.abstract: News publications continue to be pummeled by rapidly declining print advertising revenue, and newsrooms everywhere are scrambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gloom began earlier this month, when Gerard Baker, the editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, sent a memo to employees that said, in part, “every story should be as short as it needs to be.” The next week, William Lewis, the chief executive of Dow Jones, which owns The Journal, announced a newsroom review that he said would be “underpinned by a series of cost-management initiatives.”

articles.headline: Carlyle Group Turns Focus From Hedge Funds to Lending
articles.snippet: An effort to diversify goes awry as hedge fund investments weigh on the bottom line.
articles.abstract: An effort to diversify goes awry as hedge fund investments weigh on the bottom line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prominent public pension funds have turned their backs on hedge funds, and so have a few big insurance companies. Now, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, the Carlyle Group, is walking away, too.

articles.headline: Small Factories Emerge as a Weapon in the Fight Against Poverty
articles.snippet: Small manufacturers are vital if the United States is to narrow the nation’s class divide and build a society with opportunities for everyone, regardless of race or education.
articles.abstract: Small manufacturers are vital if the United States is to narrow the nation’s class divide and build a society with opportunities for everyone, regardless of race or education.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — James Branch’s life seemed destined to follow a familiar arc in the streets that surround the Marlin Steel factory, where he bends metal from sunrise until near dark.

articles.headline: Once Devoted to Suicide Bombing, She Now Embraces a Peaceful Jihad
articles.snippet: At 25, Shifa al-Qudsi wanted to kill Israelis. She failed at that, ending up in jail instead. Now, she says, “I want to stop the bloodshed.”
articles.abstract: At 25, Shifa al-Qudsi wanted to kill Israelis. She failed at that, ending up in jail instead. Now, she says, “I want to stop the bloodshed.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rami Nazzal

articles.headline: The School of Wants and Needs — and Wood-Fired Showers
articles.snippet: A prep school that prepares students for entry into competitive colleges, but also teaches them how to raise livestock, grow vegetables and chop wood.
articles.abstract: A prep school that prepares students for entry into competitive colleges, but also teaches them how to raise livestock, grow vegetables and chop wood.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN THE HILLS ABOVE SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — A day in the life of Matias Barrera looks a bit like that of many other private-school students. There is the rigorous college preparatory curriculum. And a dining hall with local organic beets, plus a cook who whips up fresh salsa.

articles.headline: Even Math Teachers Are at a Loss to Understand Annuities
articles.snippet: Schoolteachers and other government and nonprofit workers are often at the mercy of confusing contracts tied to arcane investments, sold by representatives who may not understand them.
articles.abstract: Schoolteachers and other government and nonprofit workers are often at the mercy of confusing contracts tied to arcane investments, sold by representatives who may not understand them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even a well-caffeinated person with an advanced degree in math would have a hard time deciphering a 53-page contract called “Your Flexible Premium Indexed and Declared Interest Deferred Annuity Policy.”

articles.headline: The AT&T-Time Warner Merger: A Match Built on Hope
articles.snippet: AT&T has long rewarded shareholders with one of the most sumptuous dividends on Wall Street. But the debt it’s taking on for its Time Warner deal could put that at risk.
articles.abstract: AT&T has long rewarded shareholders with one of the most sumptuous dividends on Wall Street. But the debt it’s taking on for its Time Warner deal could put that at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is AT&T’s $85 billion bid for Time Warner the triumph of hope over experience?
